column4: I'm having some issues getting public key authentication to work with an openssh server. I have not edited /etc/sshd_config from the default, although I have checked and the AuthorizedKeysFile and PubKeyAuthentication appear properly set. I have the public key that I would like to use in ~/.ssh/authorized_keys on the remote machine, but I am not prompted for a passphrase. Anyone know their way around ssh that could help me?
I should note that when I say I am not prompted for a passphrase, I mean it asks for a password, which evidently is not what I am supposed to see.
are you trying to use private key authentication/
Yes.
did you generate the RSA keys?
Yes, and I copied the contents of the public key to the authorized_keys file on the remote machine
make sure the file permissions are correct
What do they need to be set to? As of right now I have u=r,og=r
I believe it should be chmod'd to 400
let me verify that
I don't know the what the octal values correspond to off the top of my head.
it should be -r--------
Also, the various tutorials I have found online seemed to vary with regards to how permissive or otherwise they were.
or just run chmod 400 on the file
chmod 400 works fine on my debian server
tomreyn: I will try that
ah, well that would do it
Actually, I checked the file against the man page and it appears correct. Perhaps I need to restart openssh?
any time you modify sshd_conf, you should restart ssh
I was unaware.
tomreyn: It works now, thanks for your help
no prob
